item.title: Trump plans to nominate a ‘data nerd’ to lead Bureau of Labor Statistics.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: What Executives Are Saying About the ‘K-Shaped’ Economy
item.description: Leaders across industries from airlines to packaged foods have said a growing divide between lower-income and wealthy consumers is changing their businesses.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

item.title: Big Revisions Could Alter Jobs Picture
item.description: The employment report due this week is expected to show that job growth was much weaker for 2024 and 2025 than thought.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: After a Year of Sluggish Hiring, 2026 Could Be Off to a Stronger Start
item.description: Employment data for January is set to be released by the Labor Department on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Kalshi and Polymarket Create New Competition for Professional Economists
item.description: Economists have noticed that betting markets like Kalshi and Polymarket are pretty good at predicting not just political events but economic data, too.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Unemployment Rate in Focus as Fed Considers When to Restart Rate Cuts
item.description: The latest jobs data, to be released on Wednesday, will shed light on how the labor market is faring, with vast implications for the Federal Reserve’s plans for interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: The Conservative Activists Behind One of Trump’s Biggest Climate Moves
item.description: Four Trump allies have been a driving force behind the administration’s efforts to rollback a key climate regulation.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman

item.title: State Fiscal Chiefs Protest Federal Immigration Chaos
item.description: Sixteen elected treasury officials, all Democrats, wrote to President Trump to say ICE crackdowns are bad for business and tax revenues: “People must feel safe to go to work.”
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Bulgarians Adopt the Euro With a Whisper of Melancholy but Few Tears
item.description: In a country roiled by political upheaval recently, retiring the longtime currency, the lev, prompted some concern about inflation but little other angst.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Boryana Dzhambazova

item.title: ‘Neoroyalism’ and What It Says About Trump
item.description: Experts are reaching to divine the president’s approach to global policy and economics, with one theory seeing antecedents in centuries-old dynastic rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: The Global Economy’s Warning Signals Are Broken
item.description: From markets to spending to debt, usually reliable indicators that forecast where the economy is headed are proving deeply fallible.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Minnesota Economy Suffers as I.C.E. Cracks Down
item.description: Immigration raids have scared off customers and workers, a pattern repeated in other cities where federal officials have arrived in force.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Jobs Report Delayed Because of Partial Shutdown
item.description: The report, scheduled for Friday, would have provided data on job growth, unemployment and wages in January.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: Who Is Trump’s New Fed Chair Pick?
item.description: President Trump announced Kevin Warsh as his nominee to succeed Jerome H. Powell as chair of the Federal Reserve. Our reporter Colby Smith explains why the choice matters for the economy.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith, Melanie Bencosme, Sutton Raphael, June Kim and Thomas Vollkommer

item.title: Trump Picks Kevin Warsh as Next Fed Chair
item.description: If confirmed by the Senate, Kevin M. Warsh, a former governor at the central bank, will replace Jerome H. Powell, whose term as chair ends in May.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith, Tony Romm and Ben Casselman

item.title: The Fed Is Waiting and Watching an Uncertain Economy
item.description: Inflation is elevated but steady and the job market is holding up, leading economists to predict that the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates at current levels.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith

item.title: Trump’s Trade Policies Sort Manufacturers Into Winners and Losers
item.description: Tariffs have protected some companies, but more often they’ve hit the parts and materials many factories need to make finished goods.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Ana Swanson

item.title: A Rug Maker Withstood One Year of Trump’s Tariffs. New Challenges Loom.
item.description: Loloi stockpiled rugs from India, Turkey and other countries in advance, but inventory is running low.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember

item.title: What to know about the Fed decision.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Takeaways from the Fed meeting
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
